title: Stocks on Track to Snap Weekly Winning Streak; J&J shares rise premarket after The Wall Street Journal reports that the healthcare company plans to split in two
text:
A pullback in recent sessions followed data showing inflation rose to a three-decade high in October and broadened to an array of goods and services. Signs that the flare-up in inflation will last longer than central bankers had forecast prompted traders to bet the Federal Reserve would raise borrowing costs by summer.

Johnson & Johnson shares rose 3.1% in premarket trading after The Wall Street Journal reported that the healthcare company plans to split in two. U.S.-listed securities of Toshiba rose 0.8% after the industrial conglomerate said it planned to separate into three parts, following a similar path to General Electric.

Shares of electric-vehicle startups diverged before the bell in New York. Lordstown Motors dropped 10% after the company reported a loss for the third quarter. Rivian Automotive, which went public this week in the biggest U.S. IPO since 2014, rose a further 3.4% premarket. Rivian traded at $127.25 a share, well above the $78 initial offering price set Tuesday.

In other individual movers, Flowers Foods said revenues rose, pushing shares of the Tastykake owner up 3.9% premarket.

In Tokyo, Toshiba shares fell 1.3%. The industrial conglomerate said it plans to split into three parts, following a similar path to that taken by General Electric.

This fall's stock rally included the S&P 500's longest run of record highs since 1997. It was driven by expectations that central banks would keep rates at low levels, said Edward Park, chief investment officer at Brooks Macdonald. "The more we get these very high CPI prints the more that is brought into question," he said, referring to the consumer-price index.

Traders in federal-funds futures are assigning a more-than 70% probability to a rate rise by June, according to CME Group, up from just over 50% a week ago.

A key question is whether the worker shortage keeps pushing wages higher, which could feed back into inflation. Investors will get a glimpse into firms' hiring ability when the Labor Department publishes data on job openings at 10 a.m. ET. The University of Michigan's sentiment index, meanwhile, will give clues about the strength of consumer spending heading into the holiday season.

Other major U.S. indexes headed for muted moves at the opening bell. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average and technology-heavy Nasdaq-100 rose 0.2% apiece.

The bond market reopened after a break for Veterans Day. The yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury notes rose to 1.578%, from 1.558% Wednesday. Yields rise when bond prices fall.

Overseas markets were mixed. Gains for personal-goods and auto companies pushed the Stoxx Europe 600 up less than 0.1%. AstraZeneca fell 4.4% after posting a quarterly loss and saying it continued to lose money from its Covid-19 vaccine development. JDE Peet's rose 5.6%. The Dutch coffee-and-tea supplier this week said it would borrow the equivalent of around $570 million to refinance existing debt.

Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.1%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index 0.2%.

Write to Joe Wallace at joe.wallace@wsj.com
